Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an Atomic Layer Deposition Tool for Research, Education, and Outreach at Vanderbilt University
Award.AbstractNarration:
Atomic layer deposition (ALD) is a core processing technique in nanoscale science and engineering and is used for a wide variety of materials and devices ranging from electronics to biomaterials. An ALD reactor acquired through this Major Research Instrumentation award provides this capability as a shared-user facility in the Vanderbilt Institute for Nanoscale Science and Engineering, enabling innovative research, education, and outreach throughout Middle Tennessee. Vanderbilt researchers come from a wide variety of disciplines including physics, chemistry, materials science, and engineering. Furthermore, the ALD tool is accessible by students and researchers at nearby universities such as Tennessee State University, Fisk University, Belmont University, Middle Tennessee State University, University of Tennessee, and Austin Peay State University. Research enabled by the tool includes nanophotonics and optoelectronics, biomaterials and biosensors, as well as energy storage and conversion. The scientific research is tightly integrated with education, including hands-on training for undergraduate and graduate students on this state-of-the-art instrument. In addition, leveraging various outreach programs at Vanderbilt University, the impact of this project is extended to high-school students through demonstrations of fabrication of nanostructures. Moreover, the close collaboration between Vanderbilt and Tennessee State University, a historically black university, facilitates participation of underrepresented groups.

The ALD tool, installed as a shared user facility in the Vanderbilt Institute of Science and Engineering, catalyzes new collaborations among nanoscience researchers at Vanderbilt University and across Middle Tennessee. The tool is capable of deposition of atomically thin and dense metal and dielectric films as well as coating of nanoparticles. This capability enables transformative research activities addressing a broad range of nanoscience and nanoengineering areas including nanophotonics, optoelectronics, biomaterials, biosensors, solar energy conversion, and next-generation energy storage systems. In particular, the ALD enables fabrication of ultra-thin gate dielectrics as well as phase-change optics at the nanoscale. In the area of biomaterials and biosensors, the ALD enables new biocompatible coatings for both nanoscale materials as well as macroscale medical devices. In energy research, the ALD allows researchers to explore novel battery and solar cell materials as well as thermal systems and coatings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award resulted in the purchase and commissioning of an atomic layer deposition (ALD) tool, manufactured by Picosun, within the Vanderbilt Institute of Nanoscale Science and Engineering (VINSE). VINSE is a user facility located on the Vanderbilt University campus which is used by Vanderbilt undergraduate and graduate students as well as students from nearby universities such as Tennessee State University and Fisk University. The ALD allows for growth of thin films, with atomic layer precision, for applications in areas such as electronic, optics, and biological sensors.

 

The award resulted in development of a number of different film chemistries for applications across a wide range of areas. These chemistries are available to any user of the facility and VINSE is open to developing new chemistries depending on the user’s needs. The first film chemistry developed was aluminum oxide which is a material that is used heavily in electronic and optical devices. Chemistries for growth at both high and low temperatures were developed allowing deposition on a wide variety of substrates. The second film developed was titanium nitride which is to be used in biological sensors for achieving higher sensitivity in analyte detection. This material was also developed for both low and high temperature deposition enabling the use of a wide variety of substrates. Aluminum nitride was also developed alongside titanium nitride as they utilize similar growth chemistries.

The last film developed was vanadium dioxide which is a room temperature phase change material which undergoes a transition from a semiconductor to a metal at ~67 degrees Celsius. This phase change results in a drastic change in the electronic and optical properties making it an attractive candidate for electronic and optical switches. This film can be a challenge to grow while maintaining the ability to undergo a phase change but we have successfully demonstrated this capability using our tool. This capability will allow for ultrathin switchable films enabling new optical switch architectures.

There are a number of users that are utilizing these films in research projects focused on optical materials and biological sensors. Other materials including titanium dioxide, zinc oxide, and aluminum-doped zinc oxide are also under development by VINSE staff. Once the growth chemistries and conditions are determined for these films they will be made available to any user of the facility. Given the accessibility of the tool within the VINSE user facility, we expect it to enable cutting edge research across the region for many years.
